newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigeria to set up oil spillage tribunal.
newsitem.headline: Nigeria to set up oil spillage tribunal.

text.p: Nigeria's military government is to set up a tribunal for the speedy settlement of compensation cases relating to oil spillages, a senior oil ministry official said.

Wilson Dublin-Green, director of petroleum resources, told reporters in Lagos on Wednesday that the tribunal would have reputable legal experts and would determine the amount of compensation to be paid for any damage to the environment.
Oil spills are common in Nigeria where multinational companies accuse communities in oil-producing areas of damaging their pipelines in order to claim compensation.
The communities in turn accuse the companies of failing to replace ageing flowlines and pipelines responsible for the spills.
Dublin-Green said until now environmental pollution cases were handled by magistrates' courts.
A committee would also be set up to determine guidelines for assessing the level of damage caused by oil pollution and establish levels of compensation, he added.
"The tribunal will use the government-approved rates for the speedy resolution of such cases referred to it."

Nigeria's number two, General Oladipo Diya, will next week in the oil city of Port-Harcourt launch a national oil spill contingency plan aimed at giving adequate protection to the environment, he said.
